title: Principal–agent problem
summary: The principal–agent problem, in political science, supply chain management and economics (also known as agency dilemma or the agency problem) occurs when one person or entity (the "agent") is able to make decisions and/or take actions on behalf of, or that impact, another person or entity (the "principal").[1] This dilemma exists in circumstances where agents are motivated to act in their own best interests, which are contrary to those of their principals, and is an example of moral hazard.  Issues also arise when companies have an incentive to become increasingly deferential to management that have ownership stakes.[2]: 725, 741  As shareholders are dis-incentived to intervene, there are fewer checks on management.[2]: 725, 741  Issues can also arise among different types of management.
